title: The Lions, The Terps and the Workhorse Offenses of Big Ten Football
text:
Contrary to the headline, this is not a long-awaited eighth installment in the Chronicles of Narnia series. However, it is a story that audiences might find equally compelling—seeing which Big Ten offenses ran the highest average number of plays per game in the 2023 season and who is setting the tone this year.


Code
library(tidyverse)


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.3     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


Code
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(scales)



Attaching package: 'scales'

The following object is masked from 'package:purrr':

    discard

The following object is masked from 'package:readr':

    col_factor




Code
fblogs23 <- read_csv("https://dwillis.github.io/sports-data-files/footballlogs23.csv")


Rows: 1702 Columns: 54
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr   (8): HomeAway, Opponent, Result, TeamFull, TeamURL, Outcome, Team, Con...
dbl  (45): Game, PassingCmp, PassingAtt, PassingPct, PassingYds, PassingTD, ...
date  (1): Date

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.


Code
fblogs24 <- read.csv("https://dwillis.github.io/sports-data-files/footballlogs24.csv")


Looking back to last year, there was virtually a three-way tie at the top of the Big Ten with the Penn State Nittany Lions leading Purdue and Wisconsin by the finest of margins. All three schools ran an average of 71 offensive plays per game. The next closest school, Illinois, ran nearly four fewer offensive plays per game across the same span.
Unsurprisingly, the prolific punting Iowa Hawkeyes earned the lowest marks in this metric. However, this isn’t necessarily an indicator for success nor does it spell doom for teams lagging behind. Consider the fact that the national champion Michigan Wolverines, who ran roughly 61 plays per game, were only two spots ahead of the Hawkeyes. If an offense can be efficient and control the tempo of the game or a team can rely on a staunch defense to carry them, why bother running more plays at all? Food for thought.


Code
bigtenplays23 <- fblogs23 |>
  filter(Conference == "Big Ten Conference") |>
  group_by(TeamFull) |>
  summarize(avg_plays = mean(OffensivePlays)) |>
  arrange(desc(avg_plays))

ggplot(data = bigtenplays23, aes(x = reorder(TeamFull, avg_plays), y = avg_plays)) + 
  geom_bar(stat = "identity") + 
  scale_y_continuous(labels = comma) + 
  labs(
    title = "Nittany Lions Brought the Pace in 2023", 
    x = "School", 
    y = "Average Offensive Plays Per Game"
  ) + 
  theme_minimal() +
  coord_flip() +
  theme(axis.text.y = element_text(hjust = 1))









Much like the Pevensie kids stepping into the wardrobe, the 2024 Big Ten season sees a few new faces from out West in some very unfamiliar places. Former PAC-12 schools—USC, Oregon, UCLA and Washington—have joined the Big Ten ranks. Of those four schools, USC and Oregon haven’t waited for anyone to roll out the red carpet and already cemented themselves in the top three, averaging 71 and 70 offensive plays per game, respectively, through five games this season.
The bigger story here is that we have a new leader, the Maryland Terrapins, who are running an average of over 72 plays per game. Resisting the urge to name drop another classic tale, in this case involving a tortoise, we’ll have to keep an eye on the Terps throughout the year to see how sustainable this high-tempo offense is.
In terms of honorable mentions, Rutgers now finds itself in the top five with 68 plays per game, a six-play improvement from last season where it finished with the fourth-lowest amount in the conference. Nebraska and Iowa also deserve a shout as they’ve risen into the middle of the pack.
For not-so-honorable mentions, Purdue dropped nearly 18 plays per game and now sits at the bottom of the Big Ten in this metric. To put it in perspective, it’s generating almost six less plays per game than Iowa last year. It’s still early days, and we’d have to compare Iowa’s rate through five games last year to have a better idea of where Purdue actually is, but the West Lafayette side isn’t lighting it up at the moment. We’ll have to see how that story ends.


Code
bigtenplays24 <- fblogs24 |>
  filter(Conference == "Big Ten Conference") |>
  group_by(TeamFull) |>
  summarize(avg_plays = mean(OffensivePlays)) |>
  arrange(desc(avg_plays))
 
ggplot(data = bigtenplays24, aes(x = reorder(TeamFull, avg_plays), y = avg_plays)) + 
  geom_bar(stat = "identity") + 
  scale_y_continuous(labels = comma) + 
  labs(
    title = "Speedy Terps Rolling with Top Average Off. Plays Per Game", 
    x = "School", 
    y = "Average Offensive Plays Per Game"
  ) + 
  theme_minimal() +
  coord_flip() +
  theme(axis.text.y = element_text(hjust = 1))

title: Maryland Volleyball Leads Nebraska in Almost Every Offensive Scoring Metric. But the Record Doesn’t Show It.
text:
The Maryland Terrapins (10-5) have scored 108 more points than the No. 2 ranked Nebraska Cornhuskers (14-1) with eight more sets to boot this season. The way each team scores is similar too. Yet, their Big Ten conference records couldn’t be more different.


Code
md <- ncaa_vb |>
  filter(team == "Maryland") |>
  summarise(
    tot_kills = sum(kills),
    tot_blocks = sum(block_solos + block_assists),
    tot_aces = sum(aces),
    tot_opp_errors = sum(defensive_errors),
    tot_sets = sum(s)
  )




Code
md_v <- c("Kills"=714, "Blocks"=253, "Aces"=127, "Opp Errors"=323)
neb_v <- c("Kills"=701, "Blocks"=254, "Aces"=71, "Opp Errors"=283, 108)


The Terps are 1-3 to start their conference schedule, while the Cornhuskers remain a perfect 4-0. The two teams have earned a nearly identical amount of blocks. Maryland holds an ever slight edge in kills, and holds 56 more aces and 50 more opponent errors than the Big Ten leaders.
Therefore, a couple of questions remain: If the Terps and Huskers are generating points at a relatively similar rate and in a similar fashion, where does that record disparity come from? And how can the Terps turn their conference play around?


Code
iron(
 waffle(md_v/2, 
        rows = 15, 
        title="UMD Volleyball: A Relatively Balanced Attack Led by Kills", 
        xlab="1 Square = 1 Point", 
        colors = c("black", "red", "blue", "tan")
        ))











Code
 neb <- ncaa_vb |>
  filter(team == "Nebraska") |>
  summarise(
    tot_kills = sum(kills),
    tot_blocks = sum(block_solos + block_assists),
    tot_aces = sum(aces),
    tot_opp_errors = sum(defensive_errors),
    tot_sets= sum(s)
  )




Code
iron(
 waffle(neb_v/2, 
        rows = 15, 
        title="Nebraska Volleyball Relies Even Less on Aces", 
        xlab="1 Square = 1 Point", 
        colors = c("black", "red", "blue", "tan", "white")
        ))

title: Maryland Football Runs Nearly 9% More Often Than Teams Across the Country on Third and Six
text:
Maryland Terrapins head coach Mike Locksley’s first year into his current tenure saw the team produce the worst third down conversion rate in the Big Ten with 32%. The team climbed to second-best in the conference in 2023 with roughly 44%. But six games into the 2024 season, it hasn’t found the same groove and now sits at sixth-best in the Big Ten.
So let’s take a look at Maryland’s third down performance throughout Locksley’s tenure and across college football.
First we’re looking at college football play-by-play data from the 2019 season up to current day.


Code
pbp <- load_cfb_pbp(seasons = c(2019, 2020, 2021, 2022, 2023, 2024))


Then, we’re looking at all of the third down plays with six yards to go.


Code
third_and_six <- pbp |>
  filter(
    down == 3,
    distance == 6)

view(third_and_six)


When breaking all of those plays down by type, we notice that coaches across the country dialed up passing plays at a rate of nearly three to one when compared to rushing plays.


Code
third_and_six |>
  group_by(play_type) |>
  summarise(
    count = n()) |>
  arrange(desc(count))


# A tibble: 22 × 2
   play_type                  count
   <chr>                      <int>
 1 Pass Reception              4676
 2 Pass Incompletion           3866
 3 Rush                        3173
 4 Penalty                     1068
 5 Timeout                      929
 6 Sack                         800
 7 Passing Touchdown            496
 8 Interception Return          257
 9 Rushing Touchdown            135
10 Fumble Recovery (Opponent)   101
# ℹ 12 more rows


From these third and six situations, run plays were called almost 22% of the time and, on average, resulted in roughly six yard gains.


Code
rush_count <- third_and_six |> 
  group_by(rush) |> 
  filter(rush == 1) |>
  summarise(count = n()) |>
  arrange(count)

run_percentage <- third_and_six |> 
  summarise(run_pct = (3389 / 15661) * 100)

avg_yards <- third_and_six |> 
  group_by(rush) |> 
  filter(rush == 1) |>
  summarise(avg_yds_gained = mean(yards_gained))

print(rush_count)


# A tibble: 1 × 2
   rush count
  <dbl> <int>
1     1  3389


Code
print(run_percentage)


# A tibble: 1 × 1
  run_pct
    <dbl>
1    21.6


Code
print(avg_yards)


# A tibble: 1 × 2
   rush avg_yds_gained
  <dbl>          <dbl>
1     1           6.08


By filtering the data, we also see that there are 280 teams who have called run plays on third and six over the last five years. Navy leads all schools with 60 instances, followed by Army with 51 and Air Force with 42. Maryland has opted for a third and six run 17 times over the same time frame.


Code
third_and_six |>
  group_by(pos_team) |> 
  filter(rush == 1) |>
  summarise(count = n()) |>
  arrange(desc(count))


# A tibble: 280 × 2
   pos_team         count
   <chr>            <int>
 1 Navy                60
 2 Army                51
 3 Air Force           42
 4 Georgia Southern    35
 5 New Mexico          32
 6 Ole Miss            31
 7 Kent State          30
 8 Baylor              29
 9 Georgia Tech        29
10 Louisiana           29
# ℹ 270 more rows


In comparison, Maryland’s opted for runs almost 30% of the time in third and six situations, gaining nearly 6 and a half yards.


Code
md_rush <- third_and_six |> 
  group_by(rush) |> 
  filter(pos_team == "Maryland") |>
  summarise(count = n()) |>
  arrange(count)

md_run_pct <- third_and_six |> 
  summarise(run_pct = (17 / 55) * 100)
  
md_avg_yards <- third_and_six |> 
  group_by(rush) |> 
  filter(rush == 1,
         pos_team == "Maryland") |>
  summarise(avg_yds_gained = mean(yards_gained))

print(md_rush)


# A tibble: 2 × 2
   rush count
  <dbl> <int>
1     1    17
2     0    55


Code
print(md_run_pct)


# A tibble: 1 × 1
  run_pct
    <dbl>
1    30.9


Code
print(md_avg_yards)


# A tibble: 1 × 2
   rush avg_yds_gained
  <dbl>          <dbl>
1     1           6.41


During the 2023 season, the Terps successfully ran on third and six five times out of 15 attempts. They haven’t seen nearly as much success to start the 2024 season with only one successful run in nine attempts.


Code
third_and_six |> 
  filter(
    year == 2023,
    pos_team == "Maryland") |>
  group_by(rush) |>
  summarise(count = n()) |>
  arrange(count)


# A tibble: 2 × 2
   rush count
  <dbl> <int>
1     1     5
2     0    10




Code
third_and_six |> 
  filter(
    year == 2024,
    pos_team == "Maryland") |>
  group_by(rush) |>
  summarise(count = n()) |>
  arrange(count)


# A tibble: 2 × 2
   rush count
  <dbl> <int>
1     1     1
2     0     8


Here’s a distribution of Mike Locksley’s successful third down plays since 2019.


Code
md_third_down_success <- pbp |>
  filter(
    pos_team == "Maryland",
    down == 3,
    success == 1
  ) |>
  mutate(
    play_type = case_when(
      play_type == "Passing Touchdown" ~ "Pass Reception",
      play_type == "Rushing Touchdown" ~ "Rush",
      TRUE ~ play_type  
    )
  ) |>
  group_by(play_type) |>
  summarise(count = n()) |>
  filter(count >= 5) |> 
  arrange(desc(count))




Code
ggplot(data = md_third_down_success, aes(x = reorder(play_type, count), y = count)) + 
  geom_bar(stat = "identity") + 
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) + 
  labs(
    title = "Terps Want to Pass on Third Down (360 Plays)", 
    x = "Play Type", 
    y = "Count"
  ) + 
  theme_minimal() + 
  coord_flip() + 
  theme(axis.text.y = element_text(hjust = 1))









Conversely,the unsuccessful third down outcomes over the same time frame show that the Terps rely primarily on passing plays on third down.


Code
md_third_down_fail <- 
  pbp |>
  filter(
    pos_team == "Maryland",
    down == 3,
    success == 0
  ) |>
  group_by(play_type) |>
  summarise(count = n()) |>
  filter(count >= 5) |> 
  arrange(desc(count))




Code
ggplot(data = md_third_down_fail, aes(x = reorder(play_type, count), y = count)) + 
  geom_bar(stat = "identity") + 
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) + 
  labs(
    title = "Terps Aren't Afraid to Sling It (614 Plays)", 
    x = "Third Down Play Type", 
    y = "Count"
  ) + 
  theme_minimal() + 
  coord_flip() + 
  theme(axis.text.y = element_text(hjust = 1))

title: Maryland’s Lackluster Rushing Victory is Part of a Greater Offensive Trend in the Big Ten
text:
Maryland’s 29-28 Homecoming win over USC isn’t the first time a Big Ten team emerged victorious despite accumulating less than 100 total rushing yards. In fact, it’s the ninth time it’s happened this year. And it could be indicative of a changing offensive philosophy in the Big Ten over the last three seasons.


Code
ggplot(fb_tot_100_bigten, aes(x = Year, y = under_100_rush_pct)) +
  geom_line() +
  geom_point() +
  labs(
    title = "Since 2021, the Big Ten is Relying Less on the Ground Game for Wins",
    x = "Year",
    y = "Percentage of Total Wins"
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(
    breaks = seq(0, 12, by = 2),  
    limits = c(0, 12)             
  ) +
 scale_x_continuous(
    breaks = seq(2011, 2024, by = 1) 
  ) +
  theme_minimal()









Using NCAA football game logs from 2011 to present day, I was able to visualize how often this phenomenon has occurred in the Big Ten. This process involved filtering the grouping the data by year, then adding more filters to isolate wins in games with the victors producing less than 100 yards and finally calculating the percentage of instances in which its happened in relation to the total number of regular games.
Since 2021, the beloved (…or disdained depending on who you ask) grit-and-grind ground game Big Ten fans have become accustomed to could be changing as the number of games with victors producing less than 100 rushing yards has grown. Just past the halfway point in the season, Big Ten teams are three-quarters of the way to tying the highest winning percentage of the 2010s (almost 7% in 2019) in that regard.
Over the last 14 Big Ten seasons, teams have played in just over 2,300 games and won 126 of them in that fashion—at a rate of nearly 5.5%. The 2021 season blew that average out of the water, basically doubling it. Big Ten teams are slightly off pace to match that season’s figures this year. However, it’s still very possible they will come close to matching or tying it considering there are five weeks left to play.
To contextualize this trend among the entire college football landscape, I followed the same process. The result? Across 21,592 games over the same time period, teams won 4.95% of games (or 1,069 for those counting) with less than 100 rushing yards. That’s not crazy. However, what is noteworthy is the fact that the national percentage in 2021 was roughly 6.4% in comparison to the Big’s 10.5% figure.
It’s going to take a wait-and-see approach to find out how this season plays out and whether the Big Ten truly is embracing the passing game even more than before.
